intro: Galium pierredmondii, commonly known as the Sierra marshplant or Sierra gall. It is a flowering plant species native to the western United States, particularly California, where it thrives in moist, open habitats such as meadows and streambanks. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 centimeters and features slender, branched stems covered in fine hairs. Its small, white or pale blue flowers appear in clusters and bloom from late spring to early summer. Galium pierredmondii is characterized by its opposite, lance-shaped leaves and is often found in association with other wetland flora.
